text: This website currently contains two data visualization exercises.

title: Lichess.org
text:
This analysis uses data from the October 1, 2024 TidyTuesday:
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/main/data/2024/2024-10-01
This is a dataset of 20,058 online chess games. The data was collected and cleaned from Lichess.org by Kaggle/Mitchell J.:
https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/datasnaek/chess/data

# adds a column that isolates the opening move of each game, and orders it by how common each move is
chess <- chess |>
  mutate(
    opening_move = ifelse(
      str_sub(moves, 1, 1)=='N', 
      str_sub(moves, 1, 3), 
      str_sub(moves, 1, 2)
      )
    ) |>
  mutate(
    opening_move = fct_infreq(opening_move)
    )

# creates a bar plot that shows the frequency of opening moves
chess |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_bar(aes(x = opening_move)) +
  labs(
    x = 'Opening Move',
    y = 'Number of Games',
    title = 'Frequency of opening moves for white on Lichess.com'
  )








This bar plot shows the frequency of initial moves in the dataset. e4 and d4 make up almost all of them. While knight to f3 is the third most popular, almost none of the games use knight to a3.
